expanded_description: Time and temperature are fundamental measurements in physics. Time quantifies duration and sequences events, while temperature measures thermal energy intensity and heat flow direction.

core_concept.principle: Time is the measurement of duration and the ordering of events. Temperature measures the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance and determines the direction of heat transfer.
core_concept.explanation: Time is one of the seven SI base quantities, with the second as its base unit. It's unique because it flows in only one direction and cannot be directly controlled like other quantities. Temperature is also a base quantity, measured in Kelvin (K) in SI, though Celsius (°C) is commonly used. Unlike length or mass which measure 'how much,' temperature measures 'how hot' or 'how energetically particles are moving.' Understanding both is essential for describing motion, energy transfer, thermodynamics, and countless physical processes.

sections.introduction: Time is perhaps the most familiar yet mysterious quantity in physics. We experience its passage constantly, yet cannot see, touch, or control it directly.

key_concept.definition: Time is the continuous, irreversible progression in which events occur in sequence from past through present to future. It is measured as duration—the interval between events.
key_concept.context: Time is one of the seven SI base quantities, with dimension [T] and base unit second (s). Unlike spatial dimensions where we can move freely in any direction, time flows in only one direction (the 'arrow of time'). Time is fundamental to physics—it appears in equations for motion, energy, decay, oscillation, and nearly every physical process.

principles.statement: The second (s) is the SI base unit for time, defined by atomic oscillations.
principles.application: All time measurements reference the second, from microseconds to years.
principles.example: Atomic clocks define: 1 second = exactly 9,192,631,770 oscillations of cesium-133 atoms. This incredibly precise definition enables GPS, telecommunications, and scientific measurements.

principles.statement: Time has magnitude but no direction (unlike velocity or force which are vectors).
principles.application: Time intervals are always positive; we measure 'how long,' not 'in which direction.'
principles.example: An event takes 5 seconds—not '5 seconds north' or '5 seconds to the right.' Time has no directional component.

principles.principle: Time Cannot Be Created or Destroyed
principles.statement: Unlike energy or matter which can transform, time simply passes uniformly (in non-relativistic physics).
principles.application: We measure time's passage; we don't create or use up time.
principles.example: A clock measures time's passage. The time exists whether we measure it or not.

principles.statement: In everyday physics (Newtonian), time passes the same for all observers. In Einstein's relativity, time is relative.
principles.application: For Grade 9/10, treat time as absolute—the same for everyone.
principles.example: If an experiment takes 10 seconds, it's 10 seconds for everyone in the room (ignoring relativistic effects which are negligible at everyday speeds).

characteristics: Not all powers of 10 (60 s/min, 60 min/h, 24 h/day)
Mix of metric and traditional units

examples.explanation: 1 μs = 10⁻⁶ s. Computer processor operations, light travel (light travels 300 m in 1 μs).
1 ms = 10⁻³ s = 0.001 s. Human reaction time ≈ 200 ms, blink of an eye ≈ 100-400 ms.
SI base unit. Heartbeat ≈ 1 s, short events. Human walking pace ≈ 1 step per second.
1 min = 60 s. Short activities, cooking times, commutes.
1 h = 60 min = 3600 s. Class periods, work shifts, travel times.
1 d = 24 h = 86,400 s. Earth's rotation period, daily cycles.
1 y ≈ 365.25 d ≈ 3.156 × 10⁷ s. Earth's orbital period, ages, long durations.

characteristics: Varying precision from seconds to nanoseconds
classifications.behavior: More precise instruments for more demanding measurements.

examples.explanation: Precision: ±0.01 s typically. Used for: sports timing, basic experiments, everyday timing. Human reaction time limits precision to ~0.2 s.
Precision: ±0.001 s to ±0.01 s. Used for: laboratory experiments, precise event timing.
Precision: ±1 second per 100 million years. Used for: GPS satellites, telecommunications, scientific research, time standards.
Precision: ±0.0001 s (0.1 ms). Used for: measuring speed of fast-moving objects, physics experiments.

classifications.value: Different aspects of time we measure

examples.explanation: How long something takes. 'The ball took 2.5 seconds to fall.' 'The class lasts 45 minutes.'
When something occurs. 'The bell rings at 3:00 PM.' 'The experiment started at 10:23:15.'
Time for one complete cycle of a repeating event. 'A pendulum's period is 1.5 s.' 'Earth's orbital period is 1 year.'
Inverse of period—cycles per unit time. 'The heart beats at 72 beats per minute.' Units: Hz (1/s), rpm, bpm.

worked_examples.title: Converting Time Units

step_by_step.explanation: 1 h = 60 min
150 min × 60 s/min = 9000 s

worked_examples.concept_applied: Time conversions: 1 h = 60 min = 3600 s. Unlike metric units, time doesn't use powers of 10.

worked_examples.title: Measuring Time Intervals
worked_examples.problem: An object is released at time t₁ = 2.35 s and hits the ground at t₂ = 4.87 s. What is the time interval (duration of fall)?

step_by_step.explanation: Need duration—the interval between events, not the specific times
Δt = t₂ - t₁ = 4.87 s - 2.35 s
The object was falling for 2.52 seconds (from release to ground contact)

worked_examples.concept_applied: Time interval Δt = final time - initial time. The 'Δ' (delta) symbol means 'change in.'

worked_examples.title: Period and Frequency
worked_examples.problem: A pendulum completes 20 oscillations in 30 seconds. Find (a) the period, (b) the frequency.

step_by_step.explanation: Period = time for one complete cycle = total time / number of cycles
step_by_step.calculation: T = 30 s / 20 cycles = 1.5 s per cycle

step_by_step.explanation: Frequency = number of cycles per unit time = cycles / total time

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Period T = 1.5 s, (b) Frequency f = 0.667 Hz or 2/3 Hz
worked_examples.concept_applied: Period T = time per cycle. Frequency f = cycles per time = 1/T.

worked_examples.title: Precision in Time Measurement
worked_examples.problem: A student times a ball rolling down a ramp using a stopwatch that measures to 0.01 s. Three trials give: 4.23 s, 4.18 s, 4.25 s. What should be reported as the time?

step_by_step.explanation: Stopwatch reads to 0.01 s, so report to nearest 0.01 s
Trials vary from 4.18 to 4.25 s (range of 0.07 s), showing uncertainty

worked_examples.final_answer: Report time as 4.22 ± 0.04 s (average with uncertainty reflecting the spread).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Multiple measurements improve reliability. Report average and indicate precision/uncertainty.

worked_examples.title: Unit Conversion Chain
worked_examples.problem: Light travels at 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s. How far does it travel in one year (a light-year)?

step_by_step.explanation: 1 year = 365.25 days, 1 day = 24 h, 1 h = 3600 s
distance = speed × time
9.47 × 10¹⁵ m = 9.47 × 10¹² km = 9.47 trillion km

worked_examples.final_answer: One light-year ≈ 9.47 × 10¹⁵ m or 9.47 trillion kilometers.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Time unit conversions combined with speed calculations. Light-year is a distance unit, not a time unit!

sections.introduction: Temperature is fundamentally different from most other measurements—it doesn't measure 'how much' of something, but rather 'how hot' or 'how energetically particles are moving.'

key_concept.definition: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance. It determines the direction of heat flow—thermal energy spontaneously flows from higher temperature to lower temperature.
key_concept.context: Temperature is one of the seven SI base quantities, with base unit Kelvin (K). However, Celsius (°C) is more commonly used in everyday life. Temperature is an intensive property—it doesn't depend on amount. A cup of boiling water has the same temperature as a bathtub of boiling water (100°C), even though the bathtub contains much more thermal energy.

principles.statement: Higher temperature means particles are moving faster on average (more kinetic energy).
principles.application: Explains why hot things feel hot—their fast-moving particles transfer energy to your skin.
principles.example: At 100°C, water molecules move faster than at 20°C. Ice at 0°C has slower-moving molecules than liquid water at 0°C (yes, both can be 0°C during phase change!).

principles.statement: Thermal energy (heat) spontaneously flows from higher temperature to lower temperature, never the reverse without work.
principles.application: Predicts which way energy transfers when objects contact.
principles.example: Hot coffee cools down (energy flows from hot coffee to cooler air). Ice cubes warm up (energy flows from warmer air to cold ice). Never the opposite.

principles.statement: Temperature has a minimum (absolute zero: 0 K = -273.15°C) where particle motion is minimal, but no maximum.
principles.application: Kelvin scale starts at absolute zero; Celsius and Fahrenheit allow negative values.
principles.example: 0 K is the coldest possible temperature. Stars can be millions of Kelvin—no upper limit.

principles.statement: Temperature doesn't depend on amount—it's a property of the substance, not the sample size.
principles.application: Small and large samples of the same substance at thermal equilibrium have the same temperature.
principles.example: A drop of boiling water and a pot of boiling water both have T = 100°C (at sea level), even though the pot contains vastly more thermal energy.

characteristics: Different degree sizes (except Celsius and Kelvin)
classifications.behavior: Same temperature, different numbers on different scales.

examples.explanation: SI base unit. Starts at absolute zero (0 K = -273.15°C). Used in scientific calculations. No degree symbol (just K, not °K). Water freezes at 273.15 K, boils at 373.15 K.
Most common worldwide. Water freezes at 0°C, boils at 100°C (at standard pressure). Convenient for everyday use. Related to Kelvin: K = °C + 273.15
Used mainly in United States. Water freezes at 32°F, boils at 212°F. Conversion: °F = (9/5)°C + 32 or °C = (5/9)(°F - 32)

classifications.behavior: Same temperatures occur under same conditions.

examples.explanation: 0 K = -273.15°C = -459.67°F. Lowest possible temperature. Particle motion minimal (quantum zero-point energy remains).
0°C = 273.15 K = 32°F (at standard pressure, pure water)
100°C = 373.15 K = 212°F (at standard pressure, pure water)
37°C = 310 K = 98.6°F (normal, internal)

classifications.behavior: Choose instrument for temperature range and precision needed.

examples.explanation: Uses thermal expansion of liquid (mercury or alcohol). Range: -40°C to 400°C typically. Precision: ±0.5°C to ±1°C. Common in labs, homes.
Uses electronic temperature sensor (thermocouple, thermistor). Range: varies widely. Precision: ±0.1°C. Fast response, easy to read.
Measures infrared radiation to determine surface temperature without contact. Range: -50°C to 1000°C+. Used for: hot surfaces, distant objects, medical (forehead thermometers).
Junction of two metals produces voltage proportional to temperature. Range: -200°C to 1750°C. Very wide range, used in industry.

worked_examples.title: Celsius to Kelvin Conversion
worked_examples.problem: Room temperature is 22°C. What is this in Kelvin?

step_by_step.explanation: For changes in temperature, ΔT in °C equals ΔT in K (same size degree). But for absolute temperatures, add 273.15.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Kelvin = Celsius + 273.15. Kelvin starts at absolute zero; Celsius starts at water's freezing point.

worked_examples.title: Celsius to Fahrenheit Conversion
worked_examples.problem: Water boils at 100°C. What is this in Fahrenheit?

step_by_step.explanation: 100°C is water's boiling point, which we know is 212°F ✓

worked_examples.concept_applied: Fahrenheit conversion: multiply by 9/5, then add 32. Water boils at 100°C = 212°F.

worked_examples.title: Fahrenheit to Celsius Conversion
worked_examples.problem: Body temperature is 98.6°F. Convert to Celsius and Kelvin.
worked_examples.concept_applied: F to C: subtract 32, then multiply by 5/9. C to K: add 273.15.

worked_examples.title: Temperature Change
worked_examples.problem: Water is heated from 25°C to 75°C. What is the temperature change in (a) °C, (b) K?

step_by_step.explanation: ΔT = T_final - T_initial
A change of 1°C = a change of 1 K (same size degree)
step_by_step.calculation: ΔT = 50 K (same numerical value as in Celsius)

step_by_step.explanation: Celsius and Kelvin have the same degree size, just different zero points. So changes are equal: ΔT(K) = ΔT(°C)

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) ΔT = 50°C, (b) ΔT = 50 K (same value because degree size is equal)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Temperature changes: ΔT in °C = ΔT in K. The zero points differ, but degree sizes are the same.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Temperatures

step_by_step.explanation: -40 is the unique temperature where Celsius and Fahrenheit scales give the same number!
-40°C and -40°F are exactly the same temperature

worked_examples.final_answer: They're equally cold—both are the same temperature! -40°C = -40°F.
worked_examples.concept_applied: -40 is the one temperature where Celsius and Fahrenheit scales intersect.

worked_examples.title: Temperature vs Thermal Energy
worked_examples.problem: A cup (250 mL) of water at 80°C and a bathtub (150 L) of water at 40°C. Which has higher temperature? Which has more thermal energy?

step_by_step.explanation: Cup: 80°C. Bathtub: 40°C. 80°C > 40°C
The cup has higher temperature (particles moving faster on average)

Thermal energy = mass × specific heat × temperature. Bathtub has 600 times more water (150 L vs 0.25 L). Even though cooler, the bathtub's much greater mass means it contains far more total thermal energy.

worked_examples.final_answer: Cup has higher temperature (80°C > 40°C), but bathtub has much more thermal energy due to its vastly greater mass.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Temperature measures intensity (average particle energy). Total thermal energy depends on both temperature and amount of substance.

image.caption: Three temperature scales showing key reference points: absolute zero, water freezing/boiling, body temperature

sections.introduction: One of the most important concepts in thermal physics is understanding the difference between heat and temperature—they're related but not the same.

key_concept.definition: Temperature measures the average kinetic energy of particles (intensive property). Heat is thermal energy transferred between objects due to temperature difference (extensive quantity measured in Joules).
key_concept.context: This distinction is crucial. Temperature tells you 'how hot.' Heat tells you 'how much thermal energy is transferred.' You can't have a 'high heat'—you have high temperature or large heat transfer.

principles.statement: Temperature is the same throughout a substance at equilibrium, regardless of size.
principles.example: A drop of 100°C water and a liter of 100°C water have the same temperature, though vastly different amounts of thermal energy.

principles.statement: Heat (thermal energy transfer) depends on both temperature difference and amount of substance.
principles.application: More substance or larger temperature change means more heat transfer.
principles.example: Heating 1 kg of water by 10°C requires less heat than heating 2 kg by 10°C, or heating 1 kg by 20°C.

principles.principle: Heat Flows from Hot to Cold
principles.statement: Thermal energy spontaneously transfers from higher temperature to lower temperature.
principles.example: Hot soup cools (loses heat to surroundings). Ice cream melts (gains heat from surroundings). Room-temperature objects don't exchange heat—they're at equilibrium.

principles.statement: When objects reach the same temperature, heat transfer stops.
principles.application: Final temperature will be between the initial temperatures.
principles.example: Hot coffee in a room eventually reaches room temperature. Ice water warms to room temperature. At equilibrium, no net heat flow.

worked_examples.title: Temperature vs Heat Distinction
worked_examples.problem: Explain: A cup of boiling water and a swimming pool of lukewarm water (30°C). Which has higher temperature? Which contains more thermal energy?

step_by_step.explanation: Boiling water: 100°C. Pool water: 30°C. 100°C > 30°C
The cup of boiling water has higher temperature (particles moving faster)

Pool contains millions of times more water molecules. Even at lower temperature, total thermal energy = mass × specific heat × temperature. The pool's enormous mass means vastly more total thermal energy.
The cup of boiling water will burn you worse (higher temperature), but cooling the entire pool by 1°C would release far more total energy than the cup cooling completely.

worked_examples.final_answer: Cup has higher temperature (100°C vs 30°C), but pool contains far more total thermal energy due to its massive amount of water.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Temperature ≠ thermal energy. Temperature is intensive (doesn't depend on amount). Thermal energy is extensive (depends on amount).

sections.introduction: Time and temperature measurements are fundamental to physics and appear in countless real-world applications.

categories.description: Time appears in nearly every physics equation and concept.

examples.explanation: Velocity = distance/time. Acceleration = velocity/time. All motion involves time.
Pendulums, springs, waves characterized by period (time per cycle) and frequency (cycles per time).
Radioactive decay, capacitor discharge, damped oscillations all depend on time constants and half-lives.
Time dilation at high speeds—time passes differently for different observers (advanced topic).

categories.description: Temperature drives thermal processes and energy transfer.

examples.explanation: Gas laws (PV = nRT), heat engines, entropy all depend on temperature.
Melting, boiling, sublimation occur at specific temperatures. Ice ↔ water at 0°C, water ↔ steam at 100°C.
Materials expand when heated. Bridges have expansion joints, thermometers work by expansion.
Wire resistance increases with temperature. Superconductors work only at very low temperatures.

categories.description: Time and temperature in daily life.

examples.explanation: Recipes specify temperature (350°F oven) and time (bake 30 minutes). Both crucial for results.
Forecasts give temperature for comfort planning. Time of day affects temperature (hottest afternoon, coolest night).
Body temperature monitors health (fever = elevated temperature). Medication timing (every 8 hours).
Timing races, games (90-minute soccer match), performance (100m in 9.58 s). Temperature affects performance.

summary: Time is the measure of duration and the ordering of events, with dimension [T] and SI base unit second (s), defined by atomic oscillations. Common time units include millisecond (10⁻³ s), second, minute (60 s), hour (3600 s), and year (≈3.156 × 10⁷ s). Unlike spatial measurements, time flows in one direction and cannot be controlled. Period is time per cycle; frequency is cycles per time (f = 1/T). Temperature measures the average kinetic energy of particles and determines heat flow direction, with SI base unit Kelvin (K). Three temperature scales are common: Kelvin (starts at absolute zero: 0 K = -273.15°C), Celsius (water freezes at 0°C, boils at 100°C), and Fahrenheit (water freezes at 32°F, boils at 212°F). Key conversions: K = °C + 273.15, °F = (9/5)°C + 32, °C = (5/9)(°F - 32). Temperature changes are equal in Celsius and Kelvin (ΔT in °C = ΔT in K) because they have the same degree size. Temperature is intensive (doesn't depend on amount), while thermal energy is extensive (does depend on amount). Heat flows spontaneously from higher to lower temperature until thermal equilibrium is reached. Understanding the distinction between temperature (intensity measure) and heat (energy transfer) is crucial. Both time and temperature are fundamental to physics, appearing in equations for motion, thermodynamics, oscillations, and countless physical processes.
